item.title: What impact could Brexit have on the younger generation? EU Referendum Briefing 2.
item.description:
Steve Peers A UK exit from the European Union, or “Brexit,” could have significant implications for young people, impacting their education, travel opportunities, and economic prospects. Education The EU does not control educational content or matters like tuition costs. Instead, its involvement lies in cross-border educational aspects, including promoting student and teacher mobility through initiatives like the Erasmus program. Established in 1987, this EU law-based program facilitates student exchanges across various educational levels...

item.title: Brexit and the trade relations between the European Union and the United Kingdom with other countries.
item.description:
Some Brexit supporters have a relaxed view of European Union (EU) law. However, their assertions about trade after Brexit, specifically the notion that existing agreements would simply continue, require closer examination. They argue that global trade regulations would prevent the EU from hindering the UK’s trade relationships. This overlooks the possibility that, absent a transitional agreement, the UK’s participation in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) and other trade agreements could be at risk...

item.title: Is Article 50 of the Treaty on European Union considered valid?
item.description:
Bartlomiej Kulpa, LLM (London), PhD Candidate (Amsterdam) @KulpaBart Introduction The Treaty of Lisbon introduced Article 50 to the Treaty on European Union (TEU), establishing the legal framework for exiting the European Union (EU). This article acknowledges the possibility of withdrawal, a concept many legal experts believed existed even before the Treaty of Lisbon. Article 50 TEU outlines the withdrawal procedure. However, some argue that it contradicts the EU’s fundamental nature and weakens member states’ commitment to European integration, raising questions about the ideal withdrawal mechanism...

item.title: Is it possible for the UK to choose not to participate in the mandatory EU refugee quotas?
item.description:
Steve Peers The EU Commission is anticipated to unveil a new immigration and asylum agenda on May 13th. A pressing issue within this agenda is whether the UK can opt out of mandatory refugee quotas, a question this article will examine. Leaked portions of the Commission’s paper suggest a more ambitious approach to refugee resettlement than EU leaders recently agreed upon. Specifically, the Commission intends to propose mandatory rules for relocating asylum-seekers already within the EU and resettling refugees currently residing in non-EU countries...

item.title: The immigration issues in the UK renegotiation deal have been finalized.
item.description:
Steve Peers* David Cameron has successfully negotiated a deal regarding the UK’s membership in the EU. This post, the first in a series about the deal, focuses on “EU immigration” or, in terms of EU law, the free movement of EU citizens. I will delve into other important matters (competitiveness, Eurozone relations, sovereignty) and the legal structure of the deal later. The deal comprises seven legal documents: a Decision by the EU Member States’ Heads of State and Government (the “Decision”); a Statement from the Heads of State and Government (an agreed Council Decision); a Declaration by the European Council (representing the EU Member States’ Heads of State and Government); and four declarations by the Commission...

item.title: Paying tribute to Catalonia: The impact of EU law on movements for independence
item.description:
Steve Peers The recent surge in support for pro-independence parties in Catalonia has revived discussions about the connection between EU law and independence movements within member states. This issue was previously discussed in the context of the Scottish independence referendum, but it’s worth revisiting now. There are three interconnected questions: Firstly, what happens if a region within a member state declares independence unilaterally, a potential scenario in Catalonia? Secondly, if a newly independent state, formerly part of an EU member, seeks continued EU membership, what are the implications?..

item.description:

So, is a renegotiation or reform package even possible? While amending secondary EU legislation (or convincingly promising to do so) without altering the treaties is possible, there’s always a risk that such changes won’t happen or could be reversed later...

item.description:
Steve Peers David Cameron’s recent speech at Chatham House provided more specifics about the UK’s demands for renegotiating its EU membership. Cameron also outlined two planned changes to UK law regarding the EU Charter of Rights and potentially the role of UK courts in reviewing EU court decisions. As these changes pertain to domestic law, they don’t require negotiation with other Member States unless they potentially violate EU law...

item.title: The Court of Justice of the European Union clarifies the access of EU citizens to benefits after leaving employment.
item.description:
Steve Peers The recent Court of Justice of the European Union (CJEU) decision in the Alimanovic case provides further clarification on EU citizens’ access to benefits in other Member States, a complex issue. Similar to last year’s Dano ruling, it takes a stricter stance than previous interpretations of EU law. However, like its predecessor, this judgment leaves some questions unanswered. This analysis will delve into the judgment itself, its implications for EU citizens’ access to benefits, and the UK government’s plans to renegotiate its EU membership...

item.description:

This question arises from Cameron’s recently confirmed intention to secure not immediate Treaty changes, but rather a “legally binding” and “irreversible” agreement that would commit to future Treaty changes...

item.title: EU Referendum Briefing 6: The Impact on EU Employment and Equality Law Post-Brexit
item.description:
Professor Steve Peers suggests that while some claim there would be a “bonfire of rights” if the UK left the EU, particularly in employment and equality, others argue that the EU has no bearing on these laws in the UK. This post will demonstrate that EU law has significantly improved employment and equality rights in the UK, especially for women in the workplace. A study of all UK cases reaching the EU court concerning these issues reveals that 60% of cases involving equal treatment for women resulted in findings that UK law was inadequate, leading to improved workplace protections for women...
